Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 2 hour per week
None required per say, unless we had an assignment due (Ted Talk, Op-Ed). If you are reading, it'll take 1-2 hours.
2-3 hours per week
4 hours.
2-4 if it was paper writing season.  For the class in general, none, because it wasnt necessary.
On average, about 1-2.
3-4 hours.
I spent about 3 hours per week on this class.
One to three hours
3 hours
0-1 (counting session 1)
really only spent time on the op-ed assignment and the final assignment.
Spent minimal time outside of class on this course with the exception of a project or paper that was due.
Outside of the classroom I typically spent 5-7 hours on this course per week.
Typically 1 - 2, but could be up to 20 when there were deadlines
Besides reading the material, I didn't think about this class too much.
8 h/week
The take home final, op ed, and ted talk took time, everything else didn't.
2h
I spent a total of approximately 4-5 hours a week on this course from the readings.
4 hours
5 (save the final, where I spent double the amount of time studying/preparing/writing for the final compared to my other courses)

During the regular weeks, only on average an hour or two skimming the readings. For the op-ed probably over 20 hours of work. And the amount of work on the final was about 30 hours-more that was necessary for the lack of work needed all semester long.
around 8 hours
I spent a few hours a week on this course, on average.
3 hours
5 for readings and discussion preparation
Depends on the week - generally 5-7 hours outside the classroom
1 for readings. 3-4 for assignments.

0-1 hrs most weeks
4-6 hrs during the presentation week
Too many hours to count on the take home final
1 hour
3-4 hours
2 hours
2 (more when there was an assignment)
5 hours per week
2-3 on average. significantly more during weeks when assignments were due.
10 hours.
8 hours per week
About 15 hours per week, which fluctuated somewhat based on if there was an assignment due that week.
3-4 hours.
2-2.5 hours
Its strengths are that the material was presented very well and in a way that made current events relevant.

Strengths: good that it is mandatory, good overview and framework--I appreciate the explicit grounding in theoretical frameworks and research methods. Good that participation is through the takeaways, as more reserved students can still contribute.
Weaknesses: a lot of complex material that definitely merits more time--also, though theory is good, I think it is best supplemented with specific case studies or discussion of current issues because otherwise seems a bit repetitive over time. Perhaps a shorter lecture and longer discussion sections could be helpful, since discussion was a space that was a lot more engaging, material wise.

The pace at this course went made it difficult to learn because it was not clear what we were learning in class. The discussion being a week after the class makes it hard to remember what we talked about. This class should not be taught to so many people all at once. I would just make the class once a week, one hour lecture, one hour discussion, back to back.
Good

I think it is a good course to cover the general background of social justice and health equity issues. I think the discussion sections were a strength (although they seemed quite short) because they gave us the opportunity to really engage with the material. A definite weakness was the size of the class. I feel it would have been much more productive in smaller groups.

A clear strength of the course was the comprehensive material that included many different sub-disciplines. However, a weakness was the format of the course. Having the same lecturer, lecture for an hour and 50 minutes each week became monotonous. I feel like the class would have been more engaging if guest lecturers who were experts in their field came and spoke to our class.

Strengths - Great overall introduction to public health issues as well as practical implications and real-world examples. The opportunity to write an op-ed was wonderful
Weaknesses- Little opportunity to apply the material-- would have been helpful to have a couple more assignments (maybe where we could build our intervention, etc.).

Strengths: interesting content
Weaknesses: making class/discussion section mandatory

The course materials and contents are strengths. Lectures should be more concise. Harkness Auditorium is too big and there are too many students in this course to have meaningful discussions during lecture. Instead of trying to engage students in lectures,  discussion sessions led by TFs should be lengthened so that students can discuss regarding lecture materials in a small group.
good
Need to cater better to big classroom. Boring at times. Split this class with ethics.

I was not a huge fan of this course. The length of the lecture on Tuesday was not ideal, and having a discussion a week later was not confusing. I did enjoy discussion, I feel I got more out of it. I think that this class might be better served as mainly small group discussion.

Strengths: 60% of the assignments were diverse and reflected different learning styles.  I highly recommend this course.  As an EMD student, his course is incredibly accessible to those who do not have a strong sociology or psychology background.  Like any class, what you put in is what you get out. 

Weaknesses: One 5-10 page take home final exam worth 40%.  This was difficult to achieve in one week while also studying for 4 other exams as the content asked on the final was incredibly comprehensive and time-consuming.  The questions were fairly asked, but if you want to write a quality paper and answer the questions to the best of your knowledge to reflect accurately what you learned, it was just a short amount of time, as it took double the time to write as the time I took to study for other exams.

I feel that the structure of this course should change in the future, or it should be reduced to a shorter, not full-credit course. Due to the size of the class there is little time to delve into the actual subject of social justice in any meaningful way; instead, we spent most of our time talking about theory rather than actual application. This course would benefit from being redesigned to more closely look like how our Ethics course looked this semester-- we either should dedicate less, but more intense time or the course should be more focused on case studies of actual social justice issues rather than a vast smattering of topics that we have to move too quickly through.

I enjoyed the projects and assignments given to us, the Ted talk was a great way to learn and it was a fun way to start the discussion. I wish the course was in a smaller lecture hall but nonetheless, the topics were still interesting.

Overall, I think that the course should of been 1.5 hours for lecture and 1.5 hours for the discussions. There also should have been guest speakers who maybe worked specifically with the material we were learning. Trace was great but it was hard to listen to him speak for 2 hours every week. I would have loved to hear outsides speakers and understand how we can research and understand social justice in the real world. I also felt like I learned more about applications through the discussion section but never had enough time to dive into deep conversations. Also, we shouldn't discussion almost a week after we discussed the material in class. We should have the lecture on Monday and the discussion on Tuesday.

I strongly believe that all students and aspiring professionals should be exposed to the content focused on in this course. Its weaknesses included that some of the lectures got tedious at times, the videos and other teaching strategies helped to alleviate this, though.

It was a great course. I thought I knew about social justice just from being a woke millenial, but there is so much I didn't know or ever think about. The discussion section were especially helpful because they created a safe space to talk about sensitive topics.
Very interesting topics, could be more structured

It introduces many different aspects of the interactions  between social justice and public health. I love this course.
But maybe the topics are  a little vague and general.

Bad format, needs to be a half credit (share the semester with Ethics!!  Please!!).  I feel like I had the gist of this class after week 2, and didnt really need to go to class.  Theories are great, but we should have been incorporating real world case studies more.  Discussion sections were widely varied, and werent that relevant to course material, kinda all over the place.  Good, argumentative discussions werent had, and I know people have varied opinions in these topics!  This class didnt need to be boring.

Make this class a half credit!  First years have a million requirements, this didnt need to be a whole semester.
There were too many students for the structure of this course

This course was helpful in thinking about social justice issues in health and in everyday life. This is one of the few courses that has impacted by day-to-day thinking. The course was informative and important for studying public health through a social justice lens.
Increasing the discussion section time and possibly reducing lecture time would be useful for a course like this. These issues require learning from different people's experiences, and discussion gives an opportunity for students to share these experiences.
Pretty good. not a subject I am as interested in so don't have any strong opinions

I think the take-away question took away from my experience in this class. I would typically spend the entire lecture period not paying attention to the lecture because I was too busy writing my take-away since more emphasis was placed on the reading in the grading of the take-away than on the actual lecture. Because of this, I feel as if I gained almost nothing from the lectures. The ted talk and the op-ed were great assignments that I enjoyed. The final is a lot more work than I feel like a final should be. I would have rather written 5 individual papers throughout the semester than have one week to write five papers amidst all the other studying I have to do.

The class could have benefitted from having a smaller class size and meeting more than once per week. Other than that, the lectures and readings were interesting and relevant to my interests in public health and I really enjoyed my time as a student in this class. I would strongly recommend it to other students.
good
This class was taught well by the instructor. The teaching style was dull and the class time was way too long.

The course material is important and highly relevant for work in public health. One suggestion for the future would be moving discussion so that there is less time in between lecture and discussion. I also think increasing the length of discussion section would be useful. I think that the discussion is a better format to grapple with the very complex, difficult issues that we cover in the course.

This was a good basic introduction to issues of social justice in the public health field, and the topic is critical for future public health practitioners to be aware of. The lectures were too long and felt repetitive and simplistic at times. The section was really good and a good space for facilitated discussions. It's important that this course exists, but there is definitely room for improvement in terms of content and lecture style.

This course was executed extremely poorly. The incredibly long lectures were not very informative and hard to absorb. The end of lecture take away assignments were ridiculous considering how much material was covered in each lecture. To meaningfully summarize all the information and cite readings at the end of a lecture is absolutely unrealistic. Though a rubric was provided, grades that were assigned to the take away assignments and writing assignments appeared arbitrary and comments were not given for the majority of the grades assigned. This course would be better served as a seminar type class with less pressures of generating a long writing piece at the end of each lecture and focus on the learning of the concepts. So much emphasis was placed on these writing assignments that any value the lectures had were replaced with frantic typing of summary points.

While social justice is very important in the field of public health, I do not understand why every single concept in this course was labeled as racism and discrimination. Many students expressed disagreement with a lot of the content presented and I do not understand why this is a required course for 1st year students. I did not gain much from this course. A lot of the material was common sense and could have been presented to us within 2 hours rather than a whole semester. Additionally, this class is a very liberal class. I do not agree with having students take this if their views do not align, ESPECIALLY since everything in this course tries very hard to pinpoint racism as an issue for every single situation. There was a lot of content presented that I do not agree with. This course was VERY subjective and I did not enjoy it at all.

strengths: great survey of social justice and social determinants of health

cons: the structure of course impeded upon the retention of material.

Not much learned, but no real issues. I dont think this needs to be a full semester course- there just isnt enough material as structured. The discussion section was pretty good but this class does not work at all as a 200 person lecture class.
Would recommend making this half a semester and making bioethics required and graded for  half a semester.

This course was a great intro to health justice concepts and learning about the frameworks to think about exploring these topics. As an SBS student, I wish it was more in-depth or that the discussion sections were longer to facilitate further critical thinking. Overall it was a good course and a great opportunity to think about equitable ways to improve health outcomes.
Kind of messy. We bounced through a lot of topics and it's hard to engage in a large lecture, especially when only 5 students participate.

The course material is inherently interesting to me because it is about social issues, which I have always enjoyed learning about. However, how this course was taught made me strongly dislike learning about this material, which was very disappointing. The course could have incorporated things like popular culture and current events but instead it was presented by showing us strictly textbook definition vocabulary terms and concepts. The entire course is a weakness. The slow grading, the proxies for assessing student understanding of material, how our lecture had too many students and was way too long as well as having too short of discussion section to really discuss the material.
I liked the content and discussion format. The lectures were too long and I would lose focus. I think two shorter lectures per week would be better

Going into this course, I was incredibly excited. The syllabus sounded engaging, and the material we were going to cover is incredibly important to public health work. However, I was sorely disappointed. Lectures were dry and wholly unengaging. I felt no investment in the subjects that I wholly believe every public health practitioner needs to learn about. Assignments did not assist in my learning. I think the entire course needs to be restructured such that students actually engage in the material. One way to do so would be to make it a small, non-lecture course. At the very least, the lectures should be improved.

I liked that the course was divided into weekly themes. Readings could have been better integrated into lectures/discussions. The workload outside of readings was very manageable and feedback was timely. I also enjoyed the post-lecture takeaways as a way to synthesize and reflect on the day's content. 

I do feel that this course is better suited for a small discussion-based class, given the nature of the material, but I guess that is what the sections were for. 

Another aspect of the course that made me somewhat uncomfortable is that the Ted Talk (a large percent of the grade) was graded by TFs. I know that not all TFs graded the same, and I felt uneasy knowing that so much of my grade in the course was left to students only a year older than me. Of course, it wouldn't be possible for Trace to grade all of the Ted Talks, but perhaps there could be more standardization in how the Ted Talks are graded.

It was a good attempt in shifting the curriculum toward a more social justice focus but emphasized more theories than action. Even though theories are vital to understanding and implementing effective programs, I felt helpless most of the time. I was hoping this class would have me engage more intentionally and in the community. Adding a community focus like a group project as a final project instead of final essays might be more fulfilling.

I thought the class was very poorly taught. The lectures were not engaging, which is surprising given how many of us went into public health to tackle issues of social inequity. Also making lectures and section mandatory did not help; it made the class seem like simply a requirement we had to take rather than one we were actually interested in.

This course touched on a lot of important concepts that are relevant to public health and conducting research in public health. I enjoyed all the assignments such as the Ted talk and Op-ed that were done throughout the semester. However, I found the weekly discussions to be more helpful and conducive to learning than the weekly lectures. I would recommend that the discussions be made longer each week and incorporate lecture material into the discussion.

The major strength of this course are that it categorizes social justice effectively into major learning blocks - structural determinants of health, economic determinants of health, built and non-built environment, etc.  

The major weakness is that it is too fixated on research.  I understand that Yale University is a predominantly research university but there are already a plethora of courses, labs, and resources for students who want to explore social epidemiology.  We don't need another research course at YSPH.  It would be great if the course stayed predominantly fixated on implementation/grassroots work.  Maybe it can be paired with the practicum class and converted into a year-long sequence so that students gain hands on experience in a structure format.

Strengths: this class definitely has a lot of potential. It touches on very important topics pertaining to health equity and social justice. Discussions were super fun and a great space for students to feel more comfortable discussing the topics vs a larger size lecture hall. Readings are super interesting and some TED talks/videos were very touching. I enjoyed the weekly readings a lot.

Weaknesses: 1) lectures were long and dry sometimes. I think having a 2 hours of lecture straight without a break in-between can be tiring. 2) I also think the set up of the class is quite off  and I didnt like that assignments prompted us to express our opinions. Im not saying it is not important, but I think there is a level of privilege associated with ones ability to express their opinions in a platform. Some people do not like to express their opinions because of their socioeconomic position or legal position. Personally, I didnt feel comfortable writing the op-ed and I expected to get not a superb grade. I find the assignment to be borderline censoring. I thought the assignment could include another option other than the op-ed would be better so that students didnt feel like they were being graded on their opinions or how well they should express their opinions. Some people like to keep things to themselves, but that doesnt mean they are any less woke or informed. 3) Going off of that, a lot of students are not from the US - a lot came to the US for the first time. So, telling them to express their opinions about US social issues that are related directly to politics is too much to ask. Without much exposure to US cultures and politics, this was a hard task for these studentsSo, in a way, this class was not very equitable to these students. 4) I thought the final could be timed better. Writing 5 essays in a span of 7 days without prior knowledge of what to expect (i.e. there was no rubric or sample A grade response). For big assignments like that, students should have about a month in advance to prepare. Squeezing a 10 page double space paper in one week was a bit too much. I spent so much time on the final that I didnt have a lot of time to study for other finals. 5) I think having guest lecturers who are from the community would be a more refreshing approach.  I think inviting community members who do the work on the ground would be a good way to connect students from an elite institution such Yale with the community more, so that we dont run the risk of isolating ourselves with the community and just doing all the talking. We could talk about theoretical frameworks on studying social justice all day, but we would be just intellectualizing things that are so obviouswe should also be in touch with the community too. Inviting guest speakers who are from certain communities with vulnerabilities would invite more perspectives and maybe ways for students to contribute more and ways for the instructors to motivate students to show up to lectures.
I would have liked a longer discussion section and shorter lecture. Or maybe split lecture into 2 smaller size groups to facilitate group discussions better.

Strengths: Interesting material, good overarching integration of intersectionality, discussion was okay.
Weaknesses: There were a lack of rubrics, theories weren't presented as theories, take-homes were too long, a lot of studies/data was over 10+ old, class is really big for something that feels like it requires more discussion. The readings also don't always have to be reading, some topics are better covered via video or movie.

Personally, I was not a fan of this class. I find this topic incredibly informative and important to cover, but do not believe it was an effective use of our students' time. I loved the discussions, but the lectures were too long, the information was not always informative or up to date and it was honestly upsetting that we had takeaways that we had to write at the end of the class we were graded on. It required you to be in class, without excuses, and then our takeaways were graded on its accuracy, though it was supposed to be a quick summary of what we learned in class that day. I would have a much more negative experience of this course if it was not for my wonderful TF and our discussion group.

This course had a lot of potential but utterly failed. I don't think the nuanced discussions and lessons this class was trying to teach was possible in a setting of nearly 200 students. The additional section certainly made up for it. I think many of the older students who come into the program with experience in this field can feel detached, because the course material itself was sort of basic and elementary. I wish we could've had much more deep and poignant discussions about a lot of these topics that matter, but it became more about introducing basic concepts.
Prof Kershaw needs to be more open to opposing points of view. A few conservatives felt severely marginalized and discriminated against.

This course was my biggest disappointment of the fall semester. As a SBS/MPH student this course should have been fundamentally fascinating, but while all topics we discussed were important the format of the class greatly hindered its impact. Topics of relating to social justice and health equity need to be discussed in a small group format, simply lecturing at us for 2 hours a week about systemic racism and injustices does nothing.

The subject material is an extremely topic that should be discussed but seem inappropriate in a large lecture style setting. It seemed like it would have been better in a smaller seminar class. There are definitely important social justice topics covered that everyone in public health should take into consideration when preforming their work.
i feel like a 2 hour in class session every week is a bit too much and can be reduced since we also have weekly discussions
can be more structured
It is an interesting course. We got the chance to discuss the public health problems in an environment with open-minded instructors, TFs, and classmates.

I truly enjoyed my section and was able to learn more through open discussion on the topics presented in class. Having to discuss in a large sized classroom is more intimidating. The content of the course is vital to discuss for any public health professional.

This course took up more time than necessary. A two hour lecture and fifty minute discussion section is an ineffective allocation of time for this course.  If anything, lectures could be shorter and discussions could be longer. The grading of assignments seemed too harsh and specific, especially given that the prompts were fairly open-ended and seemed to allow for creativity.

Overall, I felt that I had little guidance on the material I was actually supposed to be learning from the course. I really wish that we would have had at-home weekly questions similar to the final that would have allowed us to actually work with the material rather than simply discussing the material in lectures and discussion.
It was great that a lot was packed in such a short amount of time. It feels like I have a pretty strong foundation.

Strengths:
-Small sections with well-trained TFs who led interesting discussions and provided engaging activities.

Weaknesses:
I was disappointed with this course and felt that its only function was to meet a CEPH accreditation requirement. More specifically:
-The structure of this class was flawed. It would have been far more productive to swap the length of lecture and section times -- i.e. a 50 minute lecture and ~2 hour section. We were barely able to scratch the surface in sections and often found ourselves generating compelling, creative solutions to public health problems only to be cut off before we could truly solidify our ideas. 
-Inconsistency and lack of clarity with grading rubrics, especially with the op-ed assignment.
-The final exam: our understanding throughout the semester was that if we kept up with readings and attended lectures, we would be able to reference and pull from material we learned to complete this final. This was not the case, and while I'm loath to criticize in this way (i.e. volume of work), the expectation of workload for this final was unreasonable and poorly structured. Writing one final research paper (which still could have been chosen from the prompts we were provided), rather than five short essays, would have been a better option. The questions we were asked were frankly too dense to adequately address in the required space limitations, and I would have preferred the opportunity to dive deeply into one question instead of superficially into many.

Strengths: interesting material, important information for effective public health work
Weaknesses: section could have been longer as I felt more learning took place during section, compared to lecture (and lecture often felt too long and repetitive at times). Trace is a great person but lectures by him are not always the most engaging (especially as the lectures are 2 hours long...). A lot of the information regarding health equity and social justice felt repetitive across lectures and within a lecture (although the point may be very important, it feels like the same point over and over again).

I think this course made a lot of assumptions about the class, and never addressed those assumptions. YSPH MPH students are predominantly white, and the course was clearly structured to teach to white people. It is tedious to be brown and female and sit through study after study demonstrating the relevance of intersectionality. I know. I live it. I do appreciate that my white peers are listening and learning. But I would like there to be some acknowledgement in the future that the class itself reflects inequity in the education system, and that there's a reason the course content is structured the way it is. I did really like the discussion sections, because they gave people an opportunity to debate and defend ideas. That was enjoyable, and a space for me to hone my own opinions.

This class, I feel, was a waste of time. I learned concepts that were problems that I already understood were problems, but we never really had discussions on solutions or what we can do better. It was all here's a problem, and this is why it's a problem, and there are some things you can do in a study to account for them, but never talking about solutions or things we can do better as public health professionals. I also don't think this was a good environment. I think people were often to speak their opinions or feelings because they were afraid of being judged or criticized for not being PC enough. Everything was ideal theoretically, but there was too much sensitivity and hand holding to have real conversations. I think this class could have been done in two or three lectures. I did not get anything out of it except a fear to speak to my peers about my opinions on topics because I wasn't liberal enough.
great and fun. learn a lot from the ted-talk and OpEd assignment

The course presented really important information and considerations that everyone in the health field should take to treat everyone fairly. This class could be improved if it was a smaller class for the majority of the time - I think switching the time blocks of the discussion and lecture would help make this class even better. All in all, this was a great class on  material that can be difficult to cover.
This course and type of material should not be taught in such a large environment. It has a lot of potential but just fall short on so many levels.

This course had a lot of potential to discuss social justice issues. However, I don't think the lecture was conducive to discussing these big topics and the instructor tried to make lecture a big discussion, which was not successful. I think the course would have been better if we spent more time in our classroom discussions.

Strengths: topic choice overall
Weakness: very shallow approach to very complex subject. Not meant to be a large lecture. TF's did not have exceptional knowledge. I would suggest TF's with more profound critical race theory knowledge or activist experience

I was really disappointed in this class - I think it could have offered so much more. I know Social Justice and Health Equity is a broad topic but I think the class was very poorly designed. The readings and lectures seemed rather disjointed - very dense although interesting readings that did not connect to class lecture or section. However, I did like the pairing of academic readings plus pop culture/contemporary readings - and the mixed media was a great way to break up the readings.
The sections with my TF were the best part of the class - in my opinion, the class lecture time and section time should be flipped. In other words, we should be spending more time in small groups as we discuss these big topics. Issues of social justice and health equity are not easily taught in large settings. In fact, I think the large setting was a detriment to class participation, engagement, and general understanding. Issues of justice/intersectionality/equity are incredibly important and interesting, but the large lecture setting put a damper on everything.

Strengths: fascinating readings and topics, the various topics were interwoven seamlessly, a great introduction to public health through an equity lens
Weaknesses: class size

The course has tremendous potential but really fell short. Strengths: opportunity to get everyone on the same page with regards to the basics of social determinants and health justice oriented frameworks. Weaknesses: lecturer does not compel minority students based on his race, gender, sexuality, etc. Hearing the same content from a POC or other minority in any snare would have made for a more comfortable and productive learning environment. Cases often felt abstract to the point where some students lacked empathy and genuine concern for populations examined. Grouping students in discussion sections by social justice areas of interest could lead to deeper/richer discussions. Having more colored/minority TFs is key.

Sigh...I wish this class were better than it was. 

Strengths: 
+ Covers information that public health students need to know! Mandatory discussion section was annoying but essential for learning the information

Weaknesses:
- Going to class felt like a waste of time. Since many of the topics discussed in one class sitting could be taught as an entire course itself, information covered in class was very surface level, so students who had any amount of previous exposure to this information were left wanting more. 
- The studies used in class to supplement the main discussion were often poorly described and did not seem to properly flow with what Trace was trying to communicate. Often times the conclusion seemed like a major stretch from what we were discussing in class.
- Trace could have been a better professor. I understand that he cares about this material, but the way he presented himself and the information in class gave off a vibe that he didn't.
Important and interesting concepts, but not a great course for a lecture. I wouldve preferred two discussion sections.

Very interesting course. Thought provoking. I liked the themes that Trace described throughout. The TED talk was a highlight of br course. Nerve-wracking! Instructive and helpful though with integrating material and teaching how to present in front of others.

I think the takeaways were well intentioned but they caused me to be distracted in class because I was worried about getting full credit on them. I think they sort of well self defeating in that sense.

Overall, the course was okay: I wish that we talked a little more in depth on certain topics. I think the class was great in that it touched upon the wide breadth of topics that encompasses social justice but I think that by how the class was structured (1 2-hr class a week), it almost seemed like some topics were just thrown together while some may have not been talked about enough (e.g. it would have been nice to have touched on why we see health disparities in the American Indian/Alaskan native population and the health inequities within the Asian American and Pacific Islander community). I think the class would be better if we had less in-class breakout sessions and just more time to discuss the material. I also would have liked to talk a little more about the readings during class and how those papers changed perspectives or whether some of the thoughts in those papers are disputed. Although discussion was designed to talk about the papers in depth, I feel like that also was not possible since discussion is only an hour. I think the class did help me think critically about a lot of the topics we discussed but it also could have been more hands-on. I think that the ted talk was really nice and the final was good but I wish the final was a midterm and we could have had an additional final project where we were given case studies and had to analyze how to go about developing a public health measure that is socially just and requires the knowledge that we gained from this class. This class was pretty good as a starter at discussing social justice but I think class time could have been utilized better or changing the schedule to help make the class seem less disjointed.

I very much liked the discussion sections: we were able to think critically and come up with interesting discussion topics.
The Social justice topic however, does not seem to be suited for 200 person lecture halls. Slides can become very vague and conceptual, and it is difficult to motivate and keep students interested within the context of an auditorium.
Maybe to reformulate the structure of the course...

The course tells us the definition of social justice and what aspects it covers, but I do not understand why all MPH students are required to have this lesson. It would be better if we could just have this course like health ethics, several lectures and group discussion would more beneficial and effective.

There should be no take-home finals, and not be over 10-15 pages types long during finals week, especially when its released just during finals week.  It felt more like a term paper to be honest and I think it caused a lot of stress and not the best of student's abilities because of this.

A pretty basic summary course. The grading of the lecture take-aways seemed pretty arbitrary (I put in so much effort into these- I cited 1-2 readings in each one to try to get full credit, but for some reason, I got points taken off, and there wasn't much feedback from the professor on why these points were taken off). But overall, it was a fine course.

The syllabus for this course was well curated. All the readings were interesting and supplemented the lectures very well. The lectures were engaging and relevant to topics currently being discussed around the country, which made them even more engaging. I wish we went deeper into the concepts we were learning. The course seems like an introduction to social justice topics. I also don't think the lecture takeaways were helpful. I don't think they should be part of our grade.

The component that dealt with actual health outcomes and the history leading to inequities was great but there was too much focus on deconstructing identity and intersectionality. The sections were helpful but also sometimes drifted into discussions that had nothing to do with health.

If this course will continue to be taught by a white man, I would like to see it be co-taught with a woman of color. I felt the lectures themselves were too long and would have instead like to see the course run from 3:00-4:20 and the extra 30 minutes be added to our weekly discussion groups. If the course cannot feasibly be co-taught it would have been worthwhile to bring in speakers of diverse backgrounds and abilities to discuss topics we were learning. It would have been beneficial to have the teaching fellows hold students more accountable because many never read at all and that made it difficult to have fruitful discussions. There also seemed to be gaps between the capacity for dynamic facilitation of the topics across the teaching fellows.

Really fantastic addition and extremely important for public health practitioners. I thoroughly enjoyed the course and the environment which Trace created. I would suggest that some content on disability rights be added as it is very important social issues that was not covered directly by the course.

I loved the intent and content of this course, and am very glad it's being taught as a required class at YSPH. However, it felt very basic and introductory, and covered material that I hope most MPH students would have at least a basic understanding of before beginning a graduate degree. It seemed that there was room to go farther into each of the topics addressed by asking harder questions, diving into more challenging discussion topics and pushing students beyond developing a basic social justice terminology and into building an actively antioppressive framework for their future public health work.
The structure of the course - large lecture followed by discussions facilitated by second year MPH students who were teaching for the first time - was also not conducive to asking hard questions, thinking critically, and getting into material in a deep and meaningful way. The Ted talks tended to take up most of the discussion section, so we did not get to discuss much of the course material except superficially. In order to do justice to this material and make students engage meaningfully with it, I think the discussion section needs to be more than 50 minutes per week, and to be facilitated by someone with more experience than a second year. This should not reflect on the TA for my section - it was something I heard stated by students across multiple sections, even though they liked their individual TAs.

I thought this was not a very beneficial class  especially for a introductory class. It lacked depth and the course material was very mundane and not taught in an interactive way. I find the material of social justice and health equity quite interesting but this class lacked depth. In addition, the take home final for this class was way too long and became more of burden than a practical way to test what we learned throughout the semester.
The lecture was way too long. It's really hard to focus for such a long time.

Strengths - necessary exposure to the different social determinants of health for people in all departments with different academic backgrounds as well as lived experiences. The discussion section was the most impactful as it allowed my classmates and I to discuss public health and societal issues together and see different perspectives on the same topics. 
Weaknesses - not overly engaging and not very public health solution based
I did not like that this class was offered in a 150-person lecture format. I feel that the material could be better addressed in a smaller setting.

I think the course is needed; however, I do not think two hour lectures are effective. I think a two hour discussion would be more helpful. For folks who may have a strong social justice foundation, this course may not have been as challenging.
This class had such interesting and important topics but I think it was just too big to be taught effectively. The lecture was not very engaging but the small sections were!

This is a brand new field for me. Without background cultural knowledge, I spent significant time on the subject. The class relied much on cases and reading material. As for me, those cases could be showed in a a more interesting way. The study designs could be explained more specifically.

This course is a fantastic exercise in thinking about societal issues that relate to everyday life. As well, it is a great way to examine how history and structural changes influence health of people today. Overall, I believe that this is one of the most important classes I have taken with respect to content and application to daily life. This class could be improved by having a midterm similar to the final. I think that it would be beneficial to split the final workload between two essays. If you could have three short essays around the first 5 weeks of class and three that are more comprehensive in the end, this could facilitate learning and integrating concepts as they are learned.

The course was not very much organized, I would like to see a clearer picture of the structure of the course 
Also, the questions in class discussion are too vague, there is no evaluation criteria to assess the feasibility of the answers.

This course presented a lot of really valuable information, but was very dry at times. I think it could have benefited from longer discussion sections. There also could have been more information on gender and sex-based health inequities included in our readings and discussions.

The lectures were clear and the material was interesting. However, the course offered very little room for critical discussion. I had never before had a class where I really felt that there were certain questions I couldn't ask or points I couldn't make. The class itself was quite radically to the left, and it shouldn't be assumed that we are all approaching these issues from that direction.

This class was an extremely poor way to learn social justice and health equity.  The data presented was often wrong and the studies were merely glimpsed over instead of taught in depth in the way they should have been.  The projects assigned - the TED talk, Op-Ed, take-aways, and final were incredibly time consuming and the grading requirements were subjective and unclear.  The social justice and health equity requirement could've been met by having students choose a class they wanted to take that had a social justice component.  If this class is to be repeated, provide the TFs with clear guidelines as to what they should teach, get rid of the TED talk (it's bogus, time consuming, tries to bridge together 3 incredibly vague and disconnected topics, and often the work burden falls more on one person not the other), and get rid of the take-aways.  Perhaps, design a research paper that actually forces students to present and synthesize the research we were supposed to have understood from this class.  As for the take-home final, do not put it in the middle of finals week.  Release it earlier.  It's a take-home final, not a real one, so don't put it during a time in which everyone is stressed out as is, especially, when the professor initially had told us it would be released and due prior to finals week concluding.

"Social determinants of health" is a term that I've used and heard used by others for so many years now, but I have not had many chances to sit down and test myself on what I think that means. This course was a good opportunity to think critically about concepts and frameworks that shape an understanding of human health through a social justice lens.

The material the course covered was amazing, but the delivery at times felt off. Articles assigned were long and only truly tested on during the final, which made keeping up with the material quite difficult at times. The slides went over the readings well, but there did seem to be some knowledge gap between what was assigned and what was lectured on. That being said, the material was incredible and very important. I loved the Ted Talk assignment, but as odd as it sounds, I wish we had more assignments. 90% of our grade was split between three assignments, which to me does not accurately represent the total body of work each student puts into the class.

I was a little disappointed with this course. I think it would be more beneficial to have the course broken up into 2 shorter lectures per week as opposed to 1 long lecture once a week. I found it hard to stay focused, however that's my own personal learning style. The course material was certainly interesting, but perhaps a little elementary for some students. It felt like we were learning the material solely to satisfy a course requirement. The TED Talk was fun to prepare, and it was interesting listening to my classmates' talks. The weekly discussions were generally a good supplement to the course.

While I was excited for this course at the beginning of the semester, I quickly came to dread EPH 507 week after week. The only strength this course has is that it addresses important issues in the field of public health. Its weaknesses can be examined in three broad categories:
1. Structure: This class included a 2-hour lecture on Tuesdays and a 50-minute discussion session the following Monday. Because the lecture was so long and students were more focused on the discussion session, this structure discouraged students from attending the lecture altogether. Additionally, many students (including myself) completed the readings for the Tuesday lecture, and by the time we had discussion a week later, we didn't remember the content well enough to have a productive discussion. Additionally, from the student perspective, it seemed as though Trace wanted even the lecture to take on a "discussion feel," so it was even more puzzling that between 3 hours of class time each week, less than 1 hour (6 days later) was dedicated for a small-group discussion. Overall, I think this class was trying to accomplish too much and should either be a lecture or a discussion-based class. If the instructor insists on maintaining this dual-format, the discussion should be within a couple of days of the lecture, and perhaps the lecture should be shorter and the discussion longer. 
2. Content and professor/TF: The content of this class included very sensitive topic areas and I did not think the professor nor my TF were respectful or sensitive. Both in lecture and in discussion, the professor and TF reviewed these topics at a highly-academic level. However, when students raised questions or thoughts about the content, the professor rarely waited for the student to finish his or her thought before interrupting. Additionally, student's experiences of the course overall were highly dependent on who they had as their TF. For instance, some TFs were more open and collaborative with students. This only reinforced my thoughts that this class was flawed. 
3. Assignments and grading: I fail to see how any of the assignments were useful for learning the material for this class. Creating "creative" assignments (i.e. Ted Talk rather than a presentation and op-ed rather than a paper) served only to confuse and frustrate students rather than provide an engaging platform with which students can engage with material. The assignments themselves are also extremely vague, yet the professor/TF clearly had a specific idea of what they were looking for and took points off of assignments in a way that was unclear to the students. In other words, the assignments themselves were confusing the and were harshly graded. Furthermore, I found the grading for other parts of this course to be extremely insulting for a graduate level program. 10% of our final grade was for participation based on the content and quality of what one says. While this may have been in place to encourage participation in both the discussion and in lecture, it instead caused many students to feel stress over what they wanted to contribute to discussion. In many cases (myself included), students would make sure to participate once and sit quietly during the rest of the discussion. In lectures, many students would write their take-aways either in the first few minutes of class or remotely and not attend class at all. The entire participation system caused stress and resentment among students and did not allow us to feel more engaged or connected with the material. I am confident I (and many other students) would have enjoyed this class if the assignments and grading were done in a way that made more sense for a graduate level course. 

I think this class can be improved by either eliminating it and allowing incoming MPH students to choose from a selection of SBS courses, or restructuring this course entirely. Specifically, this course would be better suited for either a lecture or a discussion setting.

Strength: I would be hard-pressed to find a more important and pressing issue in public health.

Weakness: That said, it was a very frustrating class. I found that the readings were often over-simplified in the classroom, in addition, many students rarely read the readings (nor were they incentivized to), and the classes (either large lectures or hyper-structured seminars) did not provide any opportunities to engage or wrestle with the material. I often left classes and lectures frustrated by the lack of engagement and critical thinking.

My primary suggestions to improve the class: (1) require the class in a later period  of a student's career (e.g. second semester), when students have more public health related skills to apply (e.g., epidemiology,  statistics, economics); (2) classroom discussions: just stick to carefully examining the readings (or some other shared issue); (3) Ted talks work much better when they come from someone's own experience--better to have students instead selected to lead the literature discussions.

Very good overview and introduction to concepts in the field. 

The emphasis on writing as the main means of assessment was difficult for me. The take home final, given during finals week, was new and challenging. 

Given the challenges this course posed, Dr. Kershaw was very understanding and I truly appreciate his efforts.

This class has good intentions however these are not concepts that can just be lectured at students for two hours blocks. I found the lectures to be overly simplistic and they lost my attention within minutes of every lecture. More than a few students, including myself, felt as though we were being patronized and actively dreaded going to this class. I think instead of trying to cover such broad ground on a shallow level the class would have benefited from guest speakers who have the lived experience of the topics we are discussing or at least specialize in the topic so we can dig deeper into the systemic issues at hand instead of sitting through powerpoint slides.

The scope of the class was a strength. The material was interesting, challenging, and provoked engaging conversations. The structure of the class, however, was not conducive to productive learning. With this material, I felt that the discussion sections should be longer while the lecture portion could have been condensed to a shorter time period.

Overall I think this course was interesting and provided an equal footing for students required to complete the course. I do think however that the course struggled because of its size and that the small group discussions were at times extremely unhelpful / not productive for learning. I think it could really benefit many students by having two sections of this course.

This course provides a good breadth of knowledge as it pertains to social determinants of health. However, the classes felt unnecessarily long and as though the material could be addressed in less time. The in-lecture "group" discussions were rather unhelpful. Maybe guest lecturers with backgrounds in public health programs implementation and/or research experiences in social determinants of health could be invited to speak a bit during lectures - especially when Dr. Kershaw discusses action steps to remedy inequities. I wish discussion sections were a little longer, as we often had to cut our discussions and activities short when we were just beginning to discuss inequities and determinants more in depth.

I think the discussion section should be emphasized over the lecture section. While I think the topics in lectures were useful, there were many times when Dr. Kershaw wanted to have a discussion, and doing it in an auditorium was not very productive.
Trace is awesome. He is super laid back and funny. He is a great teacher and is good at explaining concepts etc.

More clear class structure and overview of what are the goals of each day
Add case studies to lecture, maybe have things taht people think about rather than exactly discuss in class itself
Don't write on the slides with the mouse, it's very difficult to read
Trace knows what he is talking about and is very helpful. But the grading for this class was unexpectedly stringent compared to the structure of the classroom and the work we do in discussion.
Good
Trace is a great professor, and he managed to be personable with such a large group.
Trace is amazing! He truly cares about the material, however creates a relaxed learning environment  where there is not a lot of pressure to memorize all the material.

Strengths: strong lecturer, good range of content/reading
Weaknesses: powerpoints didn't always correspond with content
great
Fine, but needs to cater to larger class size better and be more enthusiastic in large classroom.

Trace is a fantastic professor.  I found his topic choices for lecture to be incredibly interesting, comprehensive, and useful.  He was able to have the class think critically about our surroundings and allowed us to participate as much or as little as we would like and still do well either way.  Trace was very understanding of student's needs, so much so that he even pushed back an assignment (whose due date was given the first day of class) two weeks, knowing we had several exams that week.
Great professor, very engaging and I value his feedback
He was fine.
Professor Kershaw is extremely knowledgeable in this arena and YSPH is truly lucky to have him on as faculty.
Trace is so sweet and I want to live in a world he designs. We judged him at first for being a white American man teaching a course about issues that barely touch him, but he did a good job.
Trace is a great instructor, thank you for teaching this class
He's very friendly and good at teaching.
More case studies, fewer theories.  More applied.  Fight for this not to be a giant lecture class....giant lecture doesnt work.  Needs to standardize TAs, as there was a ton of variablility...
Good instructor for smaller classes <200 students

Trace did a good job of keeping the lecture positive, even though some of the issues were difficult to wrestle with. I enjoyed the small group discussions in the beginning of the semester, because I think people are afraid to speak up in that class. Continuing the small group discussions throughout the semester would have been helpful to talk about the issues with peers outside of my discussion section.
Hard worker and great professor
Great professor. Very accessible, although his lecturing style was quite quick and monotone.
OK

The teaching style was poor, he seemed disinterested the entire time. I would have preferred someone who was of the minority to teach me about racism. I did not appreciate being told what racism was from a man who has never likely been on the receiving end of it.

Professor Kershaw did a great job selecting major topics for the course. I thought that his lectures were clear and the course was cohesive. I think incorporating more group discussion within lecture would be positive.

In my opinion, the instructor was not engaging and his attitude was condescending. The instructor's method of lecturing was scattered, hard to follow, and relied heavily on anecdotes, which made it at times even more difficult to follow.

I felt that Trace was a very mediocre instructor. His lectures are not engaging and the concepts presented did not stimulate me to think outside the box. Most of us have an understanding of these concepts and it was a waste of my time taking this class this semester.

strengths: genuinely concerned with student learning and checks in on student understanding

cons: the class would be less engaged near the end because of the number of concepts covered

Trace seems kind and knowledgeable. This is a challenging course to teach, and i think he did a decent job at meeting that challenge. This class just shouldnt be a lecture class and probably doesnt need to be a full semester
Trace was a great lecturer and was very receptive of feedback.
Dr. Kershaw explains a lot of the concepts clearly and simply. Makes everything a lot easier to grasp.

Trace seemed totally uninterested in the material and presented in a way that made him seem lazy and bored of lecturing. However, he is nice one-on-one and will make time to meet with you, which I definitely appreciate.
Very passionate and effective teacher. Tried to make lectures engaging which I appreciated

Despite his warning at the beginning of the class that he does not emote much, I was very disappointed. I did not think he did a good job of discussing the issues in an engaging way. He seemed bored during class, and as a result, I was, too.

Trace's lectures were interesting and I thought he did a great job engaging the class in discussion given how many students were. His feedback on the op-ed assignment also demonstrated his care for students' learning.
He is a wonderful person and researcher but can sometimes come off aloof during lectures.

Trace is extremely receptive to feedback, very friendly and empowering toward students, and incredibly knowledgeable on the course topics.  He's very resourceful and always takes the extra step beyond the classroom to connect students to internship opportunities, potential employers, research labs, etc.  My only critique is that he's not the most energetic in public-speaking so maybe supplementing some of the classes with field work would help keep students engaged.

I really appreciate Traces effort to teach this class  so it doesnt feel like people of color are tokenized to educate white students in an Ivy League school on social justice. But since Trace is a white male, I feel that there are limitations on how much he could speak about an issue, and I think he was aware of his boundaries and positionality. I think inviting non-white speakers from the community or somewhere else at Yale or other schools would bring in newer and more nuances perspectives on the issue at hand.

Trace is wonderful in other settings, but I was not too fond of his teaching styles in this class. I believe it was much too large and it did not cater to his teaching style. A class of 200+ students was addressed and asked to do activities catered for a small classroom, not a lecture. I'm sure he is great in small settings, but it did not show in this class.
The instructor needs to be more cognizant of how his own biases and stereotypes of others might influence his beliefs.
Trace's "chill" attitude just appeared lazy and he seemed basically totally un-interested in what he was talking about.

Professor Kershaw is passionate about his work but seems to have difficulty presenting the material as a large lecture. He occasionally ask questions to  students where no one appears to want to answer. It is sometimes difficult to follow the his slides and understand what he wants you to know from them.
Trace is great!!!
Great. The instructor is very patient and willing to offer help.
Great
The instructor seems passionate about the subject, but seemed to expect right answers for fairly open-ended questions. This created an awkward environment in lectures.
Engaging lecturer.

Trace is a great person but lectures by him are not always the most engaging (especially as the lectures are 2 hours long...).
Also, having participation (individuals raise their hands) in a 200-room lecture hall is not the most effective classroom structure....

Trace is an expert in his field, and it was valuable to learn from him. But I don't think Trace spent enough (or any) time addressing his own position as instructor of that course. This is something that bugged me a little bit right from the get go. Especially for a social justice course, I think it would be great for the instructor to spend a few minutes reflecting on his own identities, and how they shape his opinions and his journey to the platform he has now. I think because the class is mostly white, it's cool that a PoC or some other person with a similarly stigmatize identity is not required to expend energy teaching to a white crowd. And if that was the reason Trace teaches this course instead of someone else with lived experience, that's awesome. But it would be great to hear about that either way. Other than that, I liked Trace as an instructor. He was intelligent and funny, and his lectures were straightforward.

Trace never seemed interested or passionate about what he was teaching. It seemed most of the time that he was removed and not really even interested in what he was talking about. And then he would relate everything back to himself, and his research and how he was so great. Plus this was a class taught about social justice and the inequalities and disparities--taught by a white, privileged, straight man. It didn't make sense to me to be taught by someone with no experiences of being labelled or discriminated against from our perspectives.
very helpful and nice. easy to communicate with and would give me a lot of advice which help me a lot and help me feel relief.

Trace was a great instructor. He presented material in a way that made it blatantly obvious that it was true and important. Bringing in guest speakers for material that he didn't have a lot of personal expertise in would have been a fantastic addition to this class.

I appreciate the lecture design and set up but it was difficult for the instructor to engage with students in this lecture halls. I would especially say give me attention to who is speaking on given topics (i.e. listening to a white professor talk to only white students in a large lecture hall about racism and its effect on health)

Trace is very knowledgable on the topics taught in this course and was a good resource. However, I think his demeanor sometimes took on too much of a laid back tone for some of the heavy topics discussed.
Very good but not meant for a 300 person lecture. His research was very interesting to the field however
I think Trace is a great and clearly very experienced author. I liked the topics chosen for each week but again, I think the structure of the class is backward and unnecessarily disjointed.
This is my first time taking a class with Trace. I really enjoyed his teaching style and getting to know him better!

Kershaw is great in hearing students out and being receptive to feedback. He creates a comfortable and inclusive environment. However, this could be more compelling if taught by someone who can speak more personally to the minority plight.
Trace is awesome. Extremely knowledgeable. Self-effacing, funny, charming, and obviously very passionate. Hes a fantastic professor.
Two thumbs up. Sometimes felt like the assignments were graded harsher than expected.

Trace tried to make lectures engaging and encouraged participation but it didn't always work. I think that lecture slides could have been clearer in order to take better notes as lecture often became a discussion and was a little hard to take notes from.

I think Trace did a pretty good job overall but I felt like he could have tried to structure the class a little differently. It just always seemed like we were spending a little too much time on class breakouts but he also didn't comment on what some people said. For example, after a breakout and he would ask for people's ideas on a certain topic, sometimes people would say pretty outrageous things that were not socially just but Trace never commented on why some thoughts/programs could be problematic. I think it would have been helpful if Trace could comment on people's suggestions because I think it would have helped with everyone understanding why that idea is problematic but also bring more context/history in as to how a lot of ideas that people have are problematic due to historical context/how we were raised but we can change our mindsets. I think Trace could have challenged us a little bit more in terms of class by not just having us do breakouts but maybe showing more case studies that compare and contrast how things have been done and what pros and cons of these studies were. I also think it would have been nice to include some more history into this class because a lot of the reasons why a lot of health disparities exist is because of some historical event. I think that context would be really helpful because by learning more about the history, we can analyze how new initiatives can begin to help address some of these issues since we know that most health problems are not due to face-value issues but rather underlying, systemic, pervasive societal problems. I think Trace could also be a bit more specific about his assignments: sometimes I was never really sure what I was supposed to explain more about, especially when we had a word limit on most assignments.

Trace is a great professor and an engaging lecturer! It's obvious he cares deeply about the material he teaches and about his students. He is approachable and open to helping students with whatever situation might arise in the class. I love his teaching style and how much effort he puts in giving students the most helpful answers to our questions. I also love how understanding he is when extenuating circumstances occur. I have no suggestions for improvements. Maybe, there should be intensive and non-intensive sections where the intensive sections are geared towards students who are familiar with the concepts covered in this class while the non-intensive sections are geared towards students who are being introduced to these concepts.
The material itself was interesting but the instructor was not engaging and did not provide a safe space for students to genuinely engage.
Very compassionate and engaging. He cares about his students and leads a very interesting and comfortable lecture.
I thought the instructor did a good job with the material, but the large lecture format really put him at a disadvantage, as many students seemed disengaged and missed important material.
I believe some things Prof. Kershaw could have done in the class is be more engaging during lecture. There could have been more inactive activities as part of the discussion as well as the lecture.
Trace was very knowledgable about all topics taught, but I did not feel as though he was engaged with us as a class. More real world examples of solutions to different issues would be more impactful.
Dr. Kershaw is a competent instructor but I think that he is more effective in smaller, seminar-like settings. It is difficult to convey this material in a two-hour period to 150 people.
Great instructor. I believe the two hour lecture did not serve professor Kershaw or the students well.

I appreciate the way Trace treated our work, which was rigorous and diligent. The selected materials are interesting, but I had expected a more interesting explanation. Traces tone and also volume were too low. Sometimes I could hardly hear clearly.

Trace did a great job. I think that people in the class really respect him as a teacher and want to learn from him. I think that the teaching could be improved by changing the time of the discussion and lecture to split them more evenly. Smaller discussions are easier to participate in during these topics.

Looked as if he didn't want to be in the class as much as the students.  Many of the facts were not facts, but rather misrepresented old data.  His feedback for outlines was inconsistent with grading of the assignment and the feedback was slow!

Professor Kershaw is great, but I think he need to evaluate his tone in a few specific moments. One that sticks out is when describing our ted talk assignments and expressing how he would not like to do the assignment himself. That didn't sit too well, because I just feel like I want my professors to be excited about assignments they assign instead of expressively pessimistic, but again this was an isolated incident. Trace brought humor and seriousness to topics that were heavy, and he has introduced us all to so many assets of public health and social justice in general that will make us better public health practitioners.
Dr. Kershaw is a knowledgeable professor, and I think he did a good job presenting the course material, facilitating discussions, and including real-life examples.

I get the impression that Trace had the best intentions and high hopes for this class, and quickly became equally as frustrated as the students. While Trace clearly is passionate about the topic area of the course, I did not find him effective in a large-lecture and got the impression throughout the semester that he would have been more comfortable in a smaller setting. For example, Trace's lecture slides included routinely misinterpreted data or inaccurate data. Specifically, in one lecture about the relationship between poverty and health, Trace provided incorrect figures for the federal poverty level. Additionally, when students asked questions or tried to provide their own insights in class, he rarely allowed them to finish their thought before interrupting with his impression on what he thought the student was trying to ask. 

Trace's assignments and grading style would also clearly be better in a smaller setting. The assignments were intended to provide students an opportunity to engage "creatively" with the material in the form of a "Ted Talk" rather than a presentation and an "op-ed" rather than an essay. I'm sure Trace intended these assignments to be a nice break from other assignments in other classes, but in reality, this format coupled with the intensely vague prompt created much more confusion about the assignment itself and forced students fo focus more on the mechanics of an op-ed or a ted talk rather than understanding the material. Additionally, the 10% participation grade wherein students are graded on the content and quality of what they say may work in a small setting, but for this course (especially as a graduate level course), the participation grade was insulting and in discussion sessions resulted in some students talking just to be heard and others (including myself) making a point to say one intelligent thing and then remain silent the rest of the class time. The take-aways were equally as flawed, and I'm sure provided much more work for the professor than initially anticipated. These assignments and grading format make far more sense for a small class than a large lecture. 

Overall, Trace's teaching style is much better suited for a small, discussion-based class.

Professor Kershaw is very knowledgeable, approachable, and funny. 

I like him and found him to be a fine lecturer--I would like to see how he operates in a smaller seminar.
Excellent instructor. I would suggest the introduction of other means of assessment (e.g. quizzes, short homework assignments) in addition to essays and the TED talk.

I felt as though he had good intentions and wanted us to understand the material through discussion and assignments, however the method he went about it was poor. His lectures were not engaging, and the lack of participation was not due to the lack of interest, it was because he was hard to follow and seemed to only be looking for answers he wanted. His grading was also systematically unfair. The rubrics provided were incredibly vague while the criteria he has privately was nitpicky and asked too much out of opinion pieces with low word limits. I also found that with the end of class response pieces he was hesitant to give me full marks no matter what approach I took to my analysis, even though I attended all of the classes my participation grade doesn't reflect that.

Dr. Kershaw is really easy going and gave interesting lectures. I think it would be helpful if he could give more personal feedback to students but I realize that is difficult with such a large class. The instructor sometimes approached the class as if it were small but that did not work most of the time (for example in fielding questions from students).

Dr. Kershaw obviously knows a lot about health inequities and the social determinants of health. However, I do not think he gave enough thought to the fact that he would be teaching hundreds of students in a large lecture. His lectures could be more engaging.

I enjoyed Dr. Kershaw's lectures. He can improve by refraining from interrupting students-- it was often so frustrating to everyone that no one wanted to contribute to discussions, and the interruptions were hardly ever to add correct information or insight, but it seemed more to get the students to stop talking.
Would recommend, good overview of social determinants of health, but can be a little repetitive/very basic level if you have taken similar classes before or read about health equity in spare time.
Good

I think this is a great background course in social justice and health equity. It was required for the first years, but I elected to take it for my own knowledge. If you are already engaged in this work, you might not learn any new revelations.
Highly suggest taking it.
Good for providing a basic foundation for understanding social justice/health equity
yes very interesting course
Fine, but didn't learn a lot of new info.
Interesting and necessary for life, but not executed properly.
I would certainly recommend this course to other students, and really everyone I know. Topics discussed could not be more pertinent considering today's political and social climate.
It may not seem worth taking but it is.
Maybe. It's interesting.

Topic is important, but you dont need this class to learn the topic.  Dont take it if its not required.  Tedious antiquated theories...we never really got to the meat of the core issues that are affecting us, and our research, today.  Hopefully they change this course, and dont keep it in a giant lecture hall.
I would not recommend this class to another student. The coursework could have been presented in a much more interesting and engaging way.

Introduction to the social justice and health equity in public health research. Trace is a wonderful professor! This class is highly recommended (and is actually required for all incoming MPH students).
Good
Don't take it.

This course is a comprehensive introduction to the complex social factors driving inequities in health. I would recommend this course to anyone going into public health. I also think the course content is important for life in general. The course emphasized critical thinking and thoughtfulness when working with diverse groups of people.

This course explores the many social factors that affect health outcomes, starting by defining key social and behavioral science terms and concepts, then applying them to issues such as racism, housing, and opioid epidemic. I would not recommend this course if it stays the same. However, it is a core course so there is no option. The course is poorly designed and executed. The instructor is not constructive and the lectures are essentially a waste of time, not because of the material, which is very important, but the presentation and assignments are helpful.

This course contains concepts that unnecessarily dragged out for an entire semester. I would NOT recommend this course to another student. I did not learn a lot of useful information and the subjectivity of the class makes me skeptical. For my 1st semester at Yale, this was my least favorite course by far.
I think longer discussion sections and shorter lectures would promote better retention of material, but overall the class was great and definitely important.
Wouldnt recommend, hope the change it next year.
Overall a great introduction to health equity concepts.
