A class that teaches everything an introductory sociology course would teach, but in a less-interesting way. I would recommend this to another student only if they have had zero exposure to a class teaching any sort of social issues/concepts.
I would recommend it, I learned a lot and was exposed to different viewpoints. Its a good introduction to the field
In short, this course contains interesting material that is poorly taught. Try to get out of it what you can.

Perhaps I'm biased as an SBS student, but I really think this material is essential for all public health students to understand. After taking this course I feel much more equipped to discuss how social justice and health equity issues influence health.

This was a good first step for YSPH but needs to be further developed. It has so much potential to do wonderful work in the community but theres needs to be more of an emphasis on activism/organizing.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student and its a much needed and major improvement from the mandatory SBS courses provided last year.  I would just encourage the instructors to fixate a bit less on research and more so on grassroots work being done by local, regional, and national organizations.

This class has a lot of potential and has great content. It covers very social justice topics, and it is seriously important to learn this material as a public health professional. While this class is not a "hard skill" oriented STEM class, it provides you a lot of contextual knowledge, awareness and insights that you should incorporate in public health work.

The course has potential in a small setting, but in such a large scale and with such strict and knit-picky grading it was not conducive of learning. The best part was having such a great TF and discussion group! I think this course needs to be re-evaluated on its purpose, because right now I would not recommend it to students.
If it's structured better, maybe.
No. This course should not be mandatory.

At its current state, the course does a poor job of delivering the macro level problems that inhibit health equity. While it is necessary and the information is important, it is not worth your time to attend or do the readings week to week.

I would not recommend. While I do believe everyone should take a social justice class after learning so much about it, I feel I did not learn nearly as much as I could have. The material was not presented clearly in class or in slides.
Social justice 101
This course introduced the social science concerning public health. Students can learn how to conduct research relating to this topic and think critically.

Social Justice provides content on past and current issues that public health professionals are working with and against. It provides a foundation of knowledge on what pertinent issues plague our society today.
Yes, because she is well organized, the discussion is always going smoothly.

From my experience, the course is beneficial in that it teaches things that are crucial for public health, but is in serious need of revision in regards to instruction style and time allocation between lecture and discussion.

I would recommend this overall, however, I do think there needs to be more guidance so that students can actually feel that they gained something from the course. The way that it was set up, we talked about overarching material but did not necessarily have the terms to fully discuss the material. I would have loved a more concrete set of definition or theories to pull from to be better woven and explicitly stated in the lectures and discussion and to be given a more concrete way to review the material, such as questions to answer every week (see above). I feel that people who were already savvy to this information had a lot of room to tune out or to only pay attention to what they cared about in the realm of social justice and were not forced to challenge their beliefs and that those who do not necessarily care about these topics would have been able to take away that racism is bad and not actually engage with the material.

This course focuses broadly on issues of social justice with practical application through assignments by writing an op-ed and delivering a TED Talk.

I would not recommend the course to another student unless the structural changes addressed above were implemented.

I'd say it's a pretty comprehensive introduction to the broad fields of health equity and social justice. I'd say it mostly targets a white audience, which can be frustrating for students of color. I would still recommend it.
No. But it's required. But maybe someone else who cares about the topics should be the one teaching it.
the topics are excellent and fun. teacher and TFs are also helpful.

This is a survey course on Social justice and health equity. This class provides a handbook on the injustices both past in present that affect people and their health. Ways to improve heath equity and become a better human being and health provider are presented in this class. I would recommend this course to a fellow student because it provided extremely important knowledge that is vital for everyone entering the health field.

I think for people with limited exposure to this type of material, this course does an okay job at introducing them to it. For those with background, I would recommend trying to take other more engaging and intellectual stimulating courses.

This course is good for an overview of social justice topics for those who may have not been exposed to this kind of information before. However, I think the course could use some restructuring to make it more engaging and encourage participation. Overall, I would recommend this course for the topics discussed.
Not to any people of color, it almost felt like welcome to racism 101 for my white peers but left me very dry.  Needs to be more radical in my opinion

For students with no background in social justice or health equity (which is likely not the case in public health), this is a very cursory overview of some main issues in public health and social justice. Not for folks with any experience or exposure to the issues. Not a practical course. I would not recommend were it not a core course. I really wanted to like this course and thought based on the course name and instructor that this would be one of my favorite classes but it fell short of my expectations.
(Not that they would have a choice!), but I would recommend it to all incoming students interested in learning more about how inequities affect society at every level in complex ways.

I hope the course sees a change in instruction and organization of discussion sections. Material was alright but it did not feel meaningful when huge issues like environmental racism and medical bias were glazed over week by week. Perhaps assignments could encourage students to engage more personally by asking students to recall personal experiences as related to course material.

Sigh...I wish this class were better than it was. 

Strengths: 
+ Covers information that public health students need to know! 
+ Mandatory discussion section was annoying but essential for learning the information

Weaknesses:
- Going to class felt like a waste of time. Since many of the topics discussed in one class sitting could be taught as individual courses, information covered in class was very surface level, so students who had any amount of previous exposure to this information were left wanting more. 
- The studies used in class to supplement the main discussion were often poorly described and did not seem to properly flow with what Trace was trying to communicate. Often times the study conclusions seemed like a major stretch from what we were discussing in class.
- Trace could have been a better professor. He says that he cares about this material, but the way he presented himself and the information in class gave off a vibe that he didn't.

Fairly manageable workload for much of the semester. Dont underestimate the TED talk though! Dont try to cram too much info into it! Trace is funny as hell. This will be a very thought provoking class thatll balance off the more directly analytical core coursework in Epi and Biostats.
10 out of 10 would recommend.
The course is essentially an overview of social justice from a public health perspective.

This course is a good introduction to social justice, for anyone who has never taken a social justice class before. I would recommend it for people who have either never thought critically about social justice or has never taken a class on social justice or something similar. I think the class could have gone a bit more in-depth without seeming too overwhelming but overall still a good class.
I would not recommend this to other students. The interested students may explore with the class, but others may find it unnecessary.

I would recommend this course for a student who has little to no past experience with the social justice aspects of public health. I think students who are already familiar with the concepts covered in this course might find this class to be a review of these concepts.

The component that dealt with actual health outcomes and the history leading to inequities was great but there was too much focus on deconstructing identity and intersectionality. The sections were helpful but also sometimes drifted into discussions that had nothing to do with health.

Learning about the social determinants of health and how they create health differences among the population. While not diagnosable health issues, the social determinants of health have extraordinary effects of disease development, health outcomes and access to equitable healthcare.

I would recommend a more advanced version of this course to anyone studying public health, but would hope it becomes more in depth and less basic moving forward. It seems like a fantastic opportunity to heavily influence YSPH students' approaches to public health and commitment to social justice, but in order to do so it needs to challenge students more.
I would not recommend this course to fellow students. The class really lacked engaging teaching and the final exam was way to extensive for the class and what we learned.

It's a good foundation course but not extremely new for someone who has a bit of medical anthropology/sociology background. I'm glad all students are required to take it but there wasn't much new material for me.
I would not recommend a full course on this subject, but rather a series of shorter lectures with longer discussions. Less focus on theories and more on solution generating.
While the material addressed in this course is important, the format is not the greatest. I would recommend it to another student if the format were to change.
would recommend if the course saw a restructuring in time distribution
It's a challenge for International students. Since some of us don't have much basic knowledge of American culture, some supplement materials for international students might be of great help.

I would recommend this course to fellow students. It is an important class to take due to the bubble that Yale and most undergraduate colleges provide from the outside. It is eye-opening with respect to health issues plaguing communities of color and communities that are impoverished and how they stem from structural and historical factors.

This class has a lot of interesting and important material, but it does end up often presenting far-left ideas as if they are settled questions. There were many times when I disagreed with a particular assertion, but felt I couldn't say so or even ask a clarifying question.

Don't take it.  It was designed with good intentions but ends up being an ivory tower glimpse at some issues in social justice and health equity.  Grading is unclear and course assignments are elementary and time consuming.  There are plenty of other courses more worth your time.
The course is of critical importance. You learn topics that will upset, infuriate, and inspire you. Take everything in, engage in the course, and truly try to grasp the importance of the material.

I think the course material is something every public health should have exposure to, but I would recommend the course in a different format. I think the weekly lectures should be broken up into 2. I think the 50-minute discussions were also on the short side to fully get into a discussion after the weekly TED Talks.

This class aims to provide a foundational understanding about core concepts related to health equity. I think having this understanding is important in the field of public health, but this course did not effectively teach what it set out to do. I would not recommend this course to another student. For reasons stated above, it is a complete mess and should be re-structured for next year or completely eliminated. Frankly, after taking this class, I am hesitant to take another SBS course for fear that it will have the same fatal flaws.

Very frustrating. I could not in good conscience recommend it to another student. 

I may be wrong, but I have the impression that Yale's other professional schools (law and business) are faced with students outside their programs trying to take their core classes. I don't think I can say the same would happen for this class--and that is a problem because YSPH could offer a more engagiong class that challenged and shaped future public health practitioners.
Very interesting course and introduction to the field.
I would not. I highly recommend the administration change the format of this class.

I think the content of the social justice class should be continued as a requirement for public health students. I would encourage a restructuring of the current lecture/discussion periods to facilitate better learning.

This course is required for MPH students and is a helpful introduction to social justice concepts. However it was the first time the course existed this semester and it definitely needs some improvements and tweaks. The course struggled due to the size of the class.

I would recommend this class for students who do not have any background in the social determinants of health. However, for students with a background in community based participatory research, implementing public health programs, and working with diverse, marginalized communities, the class may be repetitive and redundant.
